stream_context.summary: Kaze iterates on Course 1’s sky/treetop area art direction (new Yoshi’s Island–themed skybox, reconsidering blocky “Minecraft” shapes) and explores re-theming the start/end structure into a large “birdhouse.” He also discusses a planned public demo (Course 1 only) meant to collect structured feedback on new physics/camera, implements a key physics tweak to sliding speed retention, and prototypes replacing a pipe/shortcut with a Yoshi’s Island–style giant flower/vine elevator mechanic guided by bunny NPC hints.
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains concrete plans for a Course 1 demo release with a feedback questionnaire, a notable physics change (sliding soft-cap), and a major design pivot for a Course 1 traversal element (pipe replaced by Yoshi’s Island flower/vine elevator) plus confirmation of removing 100-coin stars in favor of Yoshi coins.

findings.summary: Kaze is reworking Course 1’s sky/treetop sub-area visuals: the skybox was replaced/improved to be explicitly Yoshi’s Island–related, but he still feels the palette is “colorful” yet not cohesive; he considers changing mountain colors and unifying tree styles to fit the vibe.

He decides to re-theme a blocky structure into a large “birdhouse” (start/end in a birdhouse) to better fit Yoshi’s Island tone and to avoid the disliked “Minecraft blocks” look (credited as originally being “Violet’s idea”).

He implements a sliding-physics change: instead of vanilla SM64 hard-capping slide speed at 100 (instantly losing excess speed), he adds a soft cap around 95 where speed above that decays asymptotically (~5% per frame), preserving momentum when entering slides fast while keeping normal sliding feel similar.
Kaze is planning a public demo release containing only Course 1, intended primarily to validate the new physics and camera behavior before full release.

The demo will ship with a structured feedback questionnaire (Google Doc) asking about camera autorotate, pan speed, pitch limits/default pitch, Mario physics feel, and bug reports; he wants clear player data rather than relying on informal chat reactions.
findings.quote: I want more data on gameplay. I want more feedback for how people think the physics work and how the camera works and stuff like that.

findings.summary: He ties the demo timeline to his YouTube video schedule: one video already finished via an editor, aiming for roughly weekly uploads; he estimates demo timing as ideally 3–4 weeks, with an upper bound around ~8 weeks (about two months).
He notes HD background textures do consume ROM space but gives a concrete budget example: 16 textures at 0x900 bytes each (~0x9000 total ≈ 36 KB), which he considers manageable.

He highlights toolchain friction: newer Blender versions appear to have changed/broken edge splitting/vertex behavior in a way that disrupts his workflow and causes significant frustration during modeling/export.

He prefers debugging with NEMU when chasing hard bugs (assembly-level inspection) and mentions a GDB extension exists but he hasn’t set it up; he tests in other emulators too and shows that some emulator choices can cause issues (e.g., getting stuck/flicker when trying a different emulator).

He is redesigning a Course 1 traversal/entrance element: replacing a pipe/teleport-like stump feature with a Yoshi’s Island–inspired giant flower/vine that grows upward and lets Mario ride/jump up via leaves, with diegetic hints so players discover it naturally.

His puzzle-design constraint: even if bunnies can explain mechanics, he wants levels to remain beatable without talking to NPCs; interactions should feel “natural,” not like contrived puzzles, to match Mario 64’s movement-first design.
findings.quote: When you make stuff like that, you can't just turn it into puzzles. You have to make it feel really natural.

findings.summary: He outlines a specific hinting/interaction concept for the new flower: a bud that animates faster when Mario approaches; a nearby bunny reacts and optionally explains; Mario uses a Bowser-like pulling/grab animation (hold stick back or mash) to pull the bud out, causing rapid growth and enabling ascent.

He confirms a major structural change to star progression: no 100-coin stars; instead, 100-coin-star functionality is replaced by Yoshi coins (collectable across missions without losing progress) and there are no lives in the hack.
findings.quote: There's no more 100 coin star... I hate 100 coin stars in hacks most of the time.

findings.summary: Accessibility is being considered: he mentions aiming for colorblind-friendliness and also thinking about deaf players while making design decisions (e.g., relying on more than just color/sound cues).

Kaze shares two personal pressures affecting development: he recently had a daughter (~4 weeks old) impacting scheduling/planning, and he’s been feeling cognitively “slower,” attributing it possibly to stress or fatigue.
findings.quote: If you haven't noticed, I have a small child. That makes planning things really fucking difficult.

biobak.summary: Biobak gives live art-direction feedback on atmospheric depth: suggests duplicating distant tree layers and making them whiter/more transparent so trees fade into fog, improving depth in the sky area; Kaze tests and approves the look.

findings.summary: Lilaa is repeatedly referenced as a trusted helper for tool/workflow issues (Fast64 snapping/origin problems; emulator recommendations), with Kaze jokingly demanding fixes; Lilaa’s feedback influences Kaze’s iteration and testing choices.
ZeroVolt raids the stream; Kaze chats briefly and mentions his daughter was born about four weeks ago, reinforcing current life context during development.
Kaze attributes the earlier “Minecraft block” look in this area to “Violet’s idea,” and he now wants to move away from that style toward more Yoshi’s Island–consistent theming.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: When you make stuff like that, you can't just turn it into puzzles. You have to make it feel really natural.
memorable_quotes.context: Explaining why traversal mechanics (like the new flower/vine) must be discovered through natural movement and subtle cues, not overt puzzle logic.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I want more data on gameplay. I want more feedback for how people think the physics work and how the camera works and stuff like that.
memorable_quotes.context: Core rationale for releasing a Course 1 demo with a questionnaire before committing to full-release feel.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: There's no more 100 coin star... I hate 100 coin stars in hacks most of the time.
memorable_quotes.context: A clear design philosophy decision about removing a common SM64 objective and replacing it with Yoshi coins.

key_stories.title: Course 1 demo plan to validate camera and physics
key_stories.summary: Kaze outlines a plan to release a Course 1–only demo specifically to gather structured feedback on new physics and camera behavior. He intends to accompany the demo with a questionnaire asking targeted questions about autorotation, camera pan speed, pitch defaults/ranges, physics feel, and bugs.
key_stories.challenge: He doesn’t want to ship the full game without confidence that the new camera/physics feel good to a broad player base, and informal feedback is too noisy.
key_stories.process: He schedules the demo around his YouTube release cadence, plans a Google Doc questionnaire, and considers having the questions rewritten for clarity (even joking about using ChatGPT).
key_stories.outcome: A rough timeline emerges (ideally 3–4 weeks, up to ~8 weeks) and a clear data-collection strategy is established for pre-release iteration.
key_stories.key_quote: I want more data on gameplay. I want more feedback for how people think the physics work and how the camera works and stuff like that.

key_stories.title: Reworking slide momentum: from hard cap to soft cap
key_stories.summary: Kaze changes SM64 slide physics so high-speed entries don’t instantly lose momentum. Instead of a hard cap at 100, speed above ~95 decays asymptotically, preserving the sensation of carrying speed into slides.
key_stories.challenge: Vanilla sliding behavior punishes high-speed movement and can feel inconsistent with the hack’s momentum-focused feel.
key_stories.process: He adjusts the speed-capping logic to a soft-cap model where excess speed decays by a small percentage each frame.
key_stories.outcome: Sliding should feel unchanged in normal play but better when entering slides fast, supporting the hack’s movement-centric design goals.

key_stories.title: Replacing a pipe shortcut with a Yoshi’s Island flower/vine elevator
key_stories.summary: Kaze decides a stump/pipe element in Course 1 can’t remain a pipe and explores a Yoshi’s Island–authentic alternative: a giant flower bud that can be pulled out, rapidly grows upward, and functions as an ascent route via leaves or a moving spiral/elevator behavior.
key_stories.challenge: He needs a traversal solution that fits Yoshi’s Island theming, avoids contrived puzzles, and is discoverable without mandatory NPC dialogue.
key_stories.process: He brainstorms player hinting (bud animation speeding up near Mario, bunny reaction sounds, optional bunny dialogue), tests early models/collision, and pivots when climbing feels too annoying—considering an auto-moving/spinning upward plant with fade-out at the top.
key_stories.outcome: He commits to an auto-elevator style variant with a plan to fade the plant into fog using cutout/alpha tricks, but defers implementation to off-stream.

key_stories.title: Atmospheric depth fix: fog-fading tree layers in the sky area
key_stories.summary: The sky area’s tree layers looked visually flat. Through chat feedback, Kaze adjusts duplicate tree layers to fade into fog, improving depth perception.
key_stories.challenge: The scene’s colors and layering felt like “random color pixels,” lacking cohesive depth and readability.
key_stories.process: Based on Biobak’s suggestion, Kaze duplicates tree layers and adjusts whiteness/transparency to simulate distance/fog, while dealing with draw-order constraints (no z-buffer in that context).
key_stories.outcome: Kaze is pleased with the improved look and continues with art-direction changes (birdhouse concept).

key_stories.title: Newborn scheduling pressure
key_stories.summary: Kaze explains he couldn’t do a promised/teased bonus stream and attributes it to being extremely busy, emphasizing that having a newborn makes planning difficult. He briefly shares photos and notes he’s speaking to his child in German.
key_stories.challenge: Maintaining a consistent dev/stream schedule while adjusting to life with a newborn.
key_stories.process: He sets expectations (“no promises”) and acknowledges reduced flexibility; he continues development in shorter windows and leans on an editor for video production throughput.
key_stories.outcome: The project continues, but the personal context becomes an explicit factor shaping timelines and communication.
key_stories.key_quote: If you haven't noticed, I have a small child. That makes planning things really fucking difficult.

open_questions.topic: Course 1 demo scope and success criteria
open_questions.context: Kaze plans a Course 1 demo paired with a questionnaire to evaluate new physics and camera settings, with a target window of ~3–8 weeks.
questions: What is the exact definition of “success” for the demo—what feedback would cause you to revert or redesign the camera/physics?
How will you recruit testers beyond your existing audience, and how will you avoid bias from veteran SM64 players?
Will you publish aggregated results or iterate privately? What does the iteration loop look like (patches, changelog, follow-up surveys)?

open_questions.topic: Camera design: autorotate, pitch defaults, and accessibility
open_questions.context: He wants specific feedback on camera autorotation, pan speed, and pitch max/min/default pitch; he worries players won’t understand camera terminology.
questions: What specific camera problems are you trying to solve compared to vanilla SM64?
What is the current camera model (autorotate rules, triggers, speed curves), and what alternatives were considered?
How will you phrase camera questions so non-technical players can respond meaningfully?
Are there accessibility options planned (toggle autorotate, camera sensitivity presets, motion-sickness considerations)?

open_questions.context: Kaze confirms no 100-coin stars; progression uses Yoshi coins (collectable without losing progress across missions).
questions: What problems with 100-coin stars are you solving—pacing, repetition, routing, difficulty, or enjoyment?
How many Yoshi coins per course, and how are they tied to stars or completion?
How will you communicate Yoshi coin objectives to players without it feeling like busywork?

open_questions.context: Kaze proposes a Yoshi’s Island flower bud that grows and becomes an ascent route; he pivots from manual climbing to an auto-upward motion and plans a fog fade-out technique.
questions: What final interaction will trigger the flower (pulling, punching, proximity, bunny assistance), and how will you tutorialize it without mandatory dialogue?
Will the mechanic reappear in other courses/overworld, and how will you escalate it (timing challenges, hazards, secrets)?
What are the technical constraints (triangle count, collision complexity, animation system) that shape the flower’s final look and behavior?

open_questions.topic: Art direction: birdhouse theme and avoiding “Minecraft blocks”
open_questions.context: He dislikes the blocky look and wants a birdhouse-themed structure to unify the area; he’s still unhappy with color cohesion.
questions: What is the guiding art bible for RTY’s look—what makes something feel ‘Yoshi’s Island’ in 3D on N64?
How do you decide when to preserve SM64 readability versus pushing stylization?
Who is ‘Violet’ in the pipeline, and what was the original intent behind the blocky style?

open_questions.context: Kaze complains about Blender version changes affecting vertex/edge splitting; earlier snapping/origin issues in Fast64 were also referenced.
questions: Which Blender versions/plugins are ‘known good’ for your pipeline, and how do you manage version drift across collaborators?
What exactly broke in the new Blender behavior (edge split, normals, vertex duplication), and how did it affect exports to Fast64?
Do you have automated checks or a build pipeline to catch these issues earlier?

open_questions.context: Kaze uses NEMU for deep debugging (assembly) and tests other emulators; he experiences issues when switching (stuck state, flicker).
questions: What is your official emulator/hardware compatibility target for the demo and final release?
How do emulator differences influence rendering decisions (fog, transparency sorting, cutout tricks)?
What’s your bug triage process—when do you go from player report → reproduction → NEMU debugging?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions the game is ‘mostly colorblind friendly’ and they’re considering deaf players too.
questions: What specific accessibility guidelines are you using (contrast thresholds, redundant cues, subtitle-like UI)?
Are there planned options menus for accessibility, or is it primarily baked into level design?
Will the demo explicitly ask accessibility-focused questions in the survey?

open_questions.topic: Hub world plan and how it ‘glues the game together’
open_questions.context: Kaze states a big hub world is important for a Mario 64 ROM hack to unify the experience, but provides no details here.
questions: What is the hub world’s narrative/function—level selection, side quests, NPC progression, tutorials?
How does the hub evolve over time (new areas unlocked, visual changes, story beats)?
What Yoshi’s Island references are essential in the hub to establish ‘Return to Yoshi’s Island’ immediately?

open_questions.topic: Personal sustainability and schedule with a newborn
open_questions.context: Kaze notes his daughter was born ~4 weeks ago and that planning streams/dev time is difficult; he also mentions feeling mentally sluggish from stress/fatigue.
questions: How has parenthood changed your daily workflow (hours, focus, priorities) and the project timeline?
What support systems exist (Zeina, editor, community, modular tasks) to keep the project moving?
How do you prevent burnout while balancing streaming, YouTube production, and deep engine work?
